content.description: Relatively easy climbing leads to a crux slightly more than halfway up.  After the crux, fight the pump all the way up to the chains.  Fun route.
content.location: The sixth bolted route from the top (north side) of the Wall of Dancing Dwarves.  It is the second bolted route to the right of the black grungy crack.

content.description:
Pitch 1 (5.8+, BC, 8 bolts): A shorter, pumpy climb. No definitive crux, just pulling on smaller holds at the beginning until you reach a ledge and then from there it's a bunch of 5.7 moves from there to the anchors.  Not recommended for newer lead climbers due to the hard holds at the beginning and risk of hitting the large tree at the base of the climb. 

  Pitch 2 (5.10a, BC, 10 bolts)
content.protection: Bolts and chains.  The anchors at the end of each pitch consist of a bolt and chain.  If both pitches are climbed two rappels are required to descend.
content.location: The very last climb farthest to the right, just to the right of Horse of a Different Color. The first bolt is around 3 feet away from a large tree right next to the wall.

climbs.name: Pay No Attention to the Man Behind the Curtain

content.description:
Pitch 1 (65ft, 5.10d, BC, 8 bolts) From a stem box start use sidepulls and small feet to reach an intriguing, but not recommended, vertical finger slot.  Pull a small featured roof to obtain a full rest before making a final move to reach the chains.  

  Pitch 2 (50ft, 5.12a/b, BC, 7 bolts) Scramble up easy ground to obtain a ledge.  Using a shark's fin and poor feet climb into a rest below the roof, being careful not to crater onto the ledge below.  Pull the roof and subsequent intermittent crack using a grab bag of techniques including long reaches, gastons, and fingerlocks.  The climbing in this section is incredible.  Clip the chains from a well earned rest.
content.protection:
Bolts and chains.  The anchors at the end of each pitch consist of a bolt and chain. 

  The pitches can be linked with a 70m rope.  When lowering be sure to tie a knot and watch the ends as only a few feet remain.  If climbing both pitches shoulder length slings are recommended on the anchor of pitch 1 and below the roof.
content.location: Start between Emerald City and Flying Monkeys in front of and slightly right of new growth off of an old tree stump.

climbs.name: Horse Of A Different Color
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers, Mark Colby, Jay Ladin (1994)

content.description:
Two pitches of fantastic sport climbing.  Recommended. 

  Pitch 1 (90 ft, 5.11a, BC): Featured tan rock leads to a beautiful corner; pull onto a ledge and finish on devious, slightly overhanging, blocky rock. 

  Pitch 2 (50 ft, 5.10d, BC): Round the exposed corner and ascend face.
content.protection:
Bolts and chains.  If both pitches are climbed two rappels are required to descend. 

  The first pitch consists of 13 bolts and two sets of anchors.  The first set of anchors are open shuts and are optimal for the single pitch variation.  The second set are above the ledge are best for belaying on the second pitch. 

  If the pitches are linked shoulder length slings are recommended where the second pitch traverses under the roof.
content.location: Second route from the right.  Look for the obvious corner.

content.description:
First Route on the Wall of the Dancing Dwarves, just past the Wall of the Marching Munchkins; the walls are separated by a big 5th class gully(which is easy to climb up to the top and turn right to get to the other new area). It starts just left of a big tree. Pull the small pockets for some crimps a couple of small slightly juggy shelves and then sidepulls galore. 

  SQII says 11+, The online guide linked from here says 11a. I felt 11+ is much more accurate.

climbs.name: Flying Monkeys
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers, Mark Colby, Mike Strassman

content.description: Start to the right of a weakness and ascend thin edges to a roof.  The delicate journey is broken by platform jugs, allowing for full recovery.  After the roof the climbing eases to chains.
content.location: This route is located in the middle of 'The Wall of the Dancing Dwarfs' between 'Pay No Attention...' and 'Tin Man'.

content.description: Climbing on mostly good-sized holds.  One of the easier 10s at Munchkinland.
content.location: Third route from the left on the Wall of Dancing Dwarfs (farthest wall from the approach trail).  Route is left of the black stain.

content.description:
2nd route from left on Wall of Dancing Dwarves. Stars just right of a tree, almost in front of it. 

  SQII says 5.11, the online guide linked from this website says 11a. Seems more like 11a to me. I'll let the consensus determine that.
Easier climbing down low leads to a well-defined crux higher up.
content.location: Just to the right of the 5.10 route, "Dancing Dwarves"

content.description:
The Wall of the Dancing Dwarfs is located immediately to the right of the Wall of the Marching Munchkins.  The formation is a 165ft partially detached tower of blocky, golden and red rock.  The rock faces west and sees sun starting around noon, slightly earlier than the neighboring walls.  The climbs on the left are reminiscent of those found on the Wall of the Marching Munchkins while those on the right ascend larger, blocky features. 

  Three routes have second pitches.  These routes, which are frequently climbed as single short pitches, are: 

Pay No Attention to the Man Behind the Curtain P1: 5.10d, 65ft | P2: 5.12a, 50ft 

Horse Of A Different Color P1: 5.11a, 90ft | P2: 5.10d, 50ft 

Scarecrow P1: 5.8+, 65ft | P2: 5.10a, 90ft 

  These routes can be climbed as long single pitches or broken into two.  The latter two routes require two rappels to descend while the former can be rappelled with a single 70m rope.  The climber has some discretion regarding which first pitch is climbed.
